# WIRELESS FUNDAMENTALS EXERCISE
# Deploy wireless networks with proper standards and design

## SCENARIO: TechCorp Campus WiFi Modernization
## - Organization: 1000 employees across 4 buildings
## - Challenge: Replace aging WiFi with modern wireless
## - Current: 802.11n (2013 technology, slow)
## - Goal: Upgrade to WiFi 6 (802.11ax) with proper coverage

## PART 1: WIRELESS FUNDAMENTALS
## Q1: What is wireless networking?
##     Definition: _______ (data transmission without physical cables)
##     Medium: _______ (radio waves, electromagnetic)
##     Advantage: _______ (mobility, flexibility)
##     Disadvantage: _______ (security, interference, weaker signal)

## Q2: 802.11 standards:
##     802.11:
##     - Year: _______ (1997, original standard)
##     - Speed: 1-2 Mbps (very slow)
##     - Range: ~100 feet
##     - Use: Historical, obsolete
##     
##     802.11a:
##     - Year: _______ (1999)
##     - Frequency: _______ (5 GHz)
##     - Speed: 54 Mbps (better)
##     - Channels: _______ (up to 23 channels)
##     - Issues: Short range, weak walls penetration
##     
##     802.11b:
##     - Year: _______ (1999)
##     - Frequency: _______ (2.4 GHz)
##     - Speed: 11 Mbps
##     - Channels: _______ (3 non-overlapping: 1, 6, 11)
##     - Advantage: Better range than 11a

## Q3: 802.11g and 802.11n:
##     802.11g:
##     - Year: _______ (2003)
##     - Frequency: _______ (2.4 GHz, same as 11b)
##     - Speed: _______ (54 Mbps, like 11a)
##     - Backward compatible: _______ (with 11b)
##     - Issue: Can't mix 11b/11g speeds (slow to 11Mbps)
##     
##     802.11n (WiFi 4):
##     - Year: _______ (2009)
##     - Frequency: _______ (2.4 GHz AND 5 GHz dual-band)
##     - Speed: _______ (600 Mbps maximum)
##     - Technology: MIMO (multiple antennas)
##     - Channels: _______ (more channel options)

## Q4: WiFi generations:
##     WiFi 1 = _______ (802.11b, 11 Mbps, 1999)
##     WiFi 2 = _______ (802.11a, 54 Mbps, 1999)
##     WiFi 3 = _______ (802.11g, 54 Mbps, 2003)
##     WiFi 4 = _______ (802.11n, 600 Mbps, 2009)
##     WiFi 5 = _______ (802.11ac, 1.3 Gbps, 2013)
##     WiFi 6 = _______ (802.11ax, 9.6 Gbps, 2019)

## Q5: Frequency bands:
##     2.4 GHz band:
##     - Channels: _______ (1-14, depends on region)
##     - Non-overlapping: _______ (1, 6, 11 in USA)
##     - Bandwidth per channel: _______ (20 MHz, 40 MHz wide)
##     - Benefit: _______ (better range, wall penetration)
##     - Issue: Congested (WiFi, Bluetooth, microwaves)
##     
##     5 GHz band:
##     - Channels: _______ (36-165 available)
##     - Non-overlapping: _______ (many more than 2.4 GHz)
##     - Bandwidth: _______ (20, 40, 80 MHz wide)
##     - Benefit: _______ (less crowded, higher speed)
##     - Issue: Shorter range, weaker wall penetration

## Q6: Channel assignment:
##     Problem: Overlapping channels cause interference
##     
##     2.4 GHz channels:
##     - Channel 1: 2.412 GHz (covers 2.392-2.432 GHz)
##     - Channel 6: 2.437 GHz (covers 2.417-2.457 GHz)
##     - Channel 11: 2.462 GHz (covers 2.442-2.482 GHz)
##     
##     Non-overlapping design:
##     - Access Point 1: _______ (Channel 1)
##     - Access Point 2: _______ (Channel 6)
##     - Access Point 3: _______ (Channel 11)
##     - Benefit: _______ (minimize interference)

## Q7: SSID (Service Set Identifier):
##     Definition: _______ (network name, broadcast to clients)
##     Example: "TechCorp-Guest" or "Building-A-WiFi"
##     Hidden SSID:
##     - Broadcast: _______ (disabled, not visible)
##     - Security: "_______ (security by obscurity, weak)
##     - Visible SSID: _______ (recommended, not hidden)

## Q8: BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier):
##     Definition: _______ (MAC address of access point)
##     Purpose: _______ (uniquely identify AP)
##     Example: 00:1A:2B:3C:4D:5E
##     ESSID: Multiple BSSIDs with same SSID (roaming)

## PART 2: WIRELESS DEPLOYMENT
## Q9: Site survey for wireless deployment:
##     Goals:
##     - Find: _______ (optimal AP placement)
##     - Measure: _______ (signal strength, dead zones)
##     - Identify: _______ (interference sources)
##     
##     Tools:
##     - WiFi analyzer app: _______ (visualize signal, channels)
##     - Heat map: _______ (identify coverage areas)
##     - Spectrum analyzer: _______ (detect interference)

## Q10: AP placement:
##      Location principles:
##      - Centralize: _______ (roughly center of area)
##      - Elevate: _______ (higher than devices)
##      - Avoid obstacles: _______ (walls, metal, water)
##      - Spacing: _______ (typically 30-50 feet apart)
##      
##      Bad locations:
##      - Basement (distance from users)
##      - Metal closets (shields signal)
##      - Corners (poor coverage)
##      - Near microwaves (interference)

## Q11: Coverage planning:
##      Building: 40,000 sq ft office (200 ft × 200 ft)
##      
##      802.11n coverage:
##      - One AP: _______ (covers ~4,000-5,000 sq ft)
##      - Distance: ~100-150 feet reliable
##      - Needed APs: 40,000 / 4,500 = _______ (9 APs minimum)
##      
##      Overlap:
##      - Coverage: _______ (20-30% overlap for roaming)
##      - Smooth handoff: _______ (no dead zones)

## Q12: Wireless roaming:
##      Scenario: Employee moves office → WiFi changes APs
##      
##      Roaming types:
##      - Same SSID, same subnet: _______ (fast roaming)
##      - Same SSID, different subnets: _______ (full reauthentication)
##      - Different SSID: _______ (reconnection required)

## PART 3: WIRELESS PERFORMANCE
## Q13: Data rates and speeds:
##      802.11n maximum:
##      - Theoretical: 600 Mbps
##      - Real-world: _______ (150-300 Mbps, 50% overhead)
##      - Reason: MAC overhead, collision, retransmission
##      
##      WiFi 6 maximum:
##      - Theoretical: 9.6 Gbps
##      - Real-world: _______ (2-3 Gbps, overhead)

## Q14: Signal strength (RSSI):
##      RSSI = Received Signal Strength Indicator
##      
##      Typical values:
##      - Excellent: _______ (> -50 dBm, very strong)
##      - Good: _______ (-50 to -60 dBm, strong)
##      - Fair: _______ (-60 to -70 dBm, acceptable)
##      - Weak: _______ (-70 to -80 dBm, poor)
##      - No signal: _______ (< -80 dBm, disconnected)

## Q15: Channel bonding (wider channels):
##      Concept: _______ (combine adjacent channels for speed)
##      
##      802.11n channels:
##      - 20 MHz: Standard, 3 non-overlapping
##      - 40 MHz: _______ (two 20 MHz channels combined)
##      - Benefit: _______ (doubled throughput)
##      - Issue: _______ (only 1 non-overlapping combo in 2.4 GHz)

## Q16: Throughput vs bandwidth:
##      Bandwidth:
##      - Definition: _______ (frequency range used)
##      - Example: 20 MHz channel
##      - Measurement: Frequency (Hz)
##      
##      Throughput:
##      - Definition: _______ (actual data rate achieved)
##      - Example: 150 Mbps on 802.11n
##      - Measurement: bits/second (Mbps)

## PART 4: WIRELESS TECHNOLOGIES
## Q17: MIMO (Multiple-Input, Multiple-Output):
##      Technology: _______ (multiple antennas for better signal)
##      
##      Single antenna (11a/11g):
##      - APs: _______ (1 antenna)
##      - Speed: 54 Mbps
##      
##      MIMO (11n/11ac/11ax):
##      - APs: _______ (2-8+ antennas)
##      - Speed: _______ (higher throughput, reliability)

## Q18: Beamforming:
##      Purpose: _______ (focus signal toward client)
##      Benefit: _______ (improved signal, range, throughput)
##      Support: _______ (11ac and later)

## Q19: MU-MIMO (Multi-User MIMO):
##      Traditional MIMO:
##      - Service: _______ (one client at a time)
##      - Issue: _______ (others wait their turn)
##      
##      MU-MIMO (11ac/11ax):
##      - Service: _______ (multiple clients simultaneously)
##      - Benefit: _______ (higher total throughput)

## Q20: OFDM (Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing):
##      Purpose: _______ (divide channel into subcarriers)
##      Benefit: _______ (robust to interference, reflection)
##      Implementation: _______ (802.11a and later use OFDM)

## PART 5: WIRELESS CHALLENGES
## Q21: Interference sources:
##      2.4 GHz interference:
##      - Microwave ovens: _______ (strong interference)
##      - Cordless phones: _______ (overlapping frequency)
##      - Bluetooth: _______ (same 2.4 GHz band)
##      - Other WiFi: _______ (adjacent channels)
##      
##      Solutions:
##      - Use 5 GHz: _______ (less congested)
##      - Channel selection: _______ (channels 1, 6, 11)

## Q22: Obstacles and signal attenuation:
##      Free space:
##      - Path loss: _______ (minimal, clear line-of-sight)
##      - Signal: Strong
##      
##      Obstacles reduce signal:
##      - Drywall: _______ (-3 dB, some attenuation)
##      - Wood/glass: _______ (-5 dB)
##      - Metal doors: _______ (-15 dB, major)
##      - Concrete: _______ (-10 dB, significant)

## Q23: Power management:
##      AP transmit power:
##      - Range: _______ (1-30 dBm depending region)
##      - Higher: _______ (more range, but higher cost)
##      - Regulation: _______ (FCC limits USA)
##      
##      Client power saving:
##      - Sleep mode: _______ (reduces battery usage)
##      - Wake on wireless: _______ (quick reconnect)

## Q24: Multipath and fading:
##      Multipath:
##      - Cause: _______ (signal bounces off obstacles)
##      - Effect: _______ (constructive/destructive interference)
##      - Result: _______ (varying signal strength)
##      
##      Fading types:
##      - Small-scale: _______ (rapid changes)
##      - Large-scale: _______ (distance-based attenuation)

## PART 6: WIRELESS STANDARDS EVOLUTION
## Q25: 802.11 improvements over time:
##      Data rate progression:
##      - 1997: _______ (1-2 Mbps)
##      - 1999: _______ (54 Mbps)
##      - 2009: _______ (600 Mbps)
##      - 2013: _______ (1.3 Gbps)
##      - 2019: _______ (9.6 Gbps)
##      
##      Drivers: More antennas, wider channels, better coding

## Q26: 6 GHz spectrum (802.11ax+):
##      New band: _______ (6 GHz frequency range)
##      Availability: _______ (newer WiFi 6E devices)
##      Channels: _______ (many more channels available)
##      Benefit: _______ (less congestion, improved performance)

## Q27: Backward compatibility:
##      Example: New 802.11ac AP with old 802.11g client
##      
##      What happens:
##      - AP detects: _______ (old client present)
##      - Operation: _______ (slows to support old device)
##      - Speed: _______ (limited to lowest client speed)

## Q28: Planning for future:
##      Deployment checklist:
##      - Current needs: _______ (assess bandwidth)
##      - Growth: _______ (plan 3-5 year expansion)
##      - Standard: _______ (use latest stable standard)
##      - Vendor support: _______ (long-term updates)
##      - Budget: _______ (initial + refresh costs)

# WIRELESS FUNDAMENTALS SOLUTION

## PART 1: WIRELESS FUNDAMENTALS

### What is Wireless Networking?

**Definition**: **DATA TRANSMISSION WITHOUT PHYSICAL CABLES** ✓
**Medium**: **RADIO WAVES, ELECTROMAGNETIC** ✓
**Advantage**: **MOBILITY, FLEXIBILITY** ✓
**Disadvantage**: **SECURITY, INTERFERENCE, WEAKER SIGNAL** ✓

### 802.11 Standards

**802.11**:
- Year: **1997, ORIGINAL STANDARD** ✓
- Speed: 1-2 Mbps (very slow)
- Range: ~100 feet
- Use: Historical, obsolete

**802.11a**:
- Year: **1999** ✓
- Frequency: **5 GHZ** ✓
- Speed: 54 Mbps (better)
- Channels: **UP TO 23 CHANNELS** ✓
- Issues: Short range, weak walls penetration

**802.11b**:
- Year: **1999** ✓
- Frequency: **2.4 GHZ** ✓
- Speed: 11 Mbps
- Channels: **3 NON-OVERLAPPING (1, 6, 11)** ✓
- Advantage: Better range than 11a

### 802.11g and 802.11n

**802.11g**:
- Year: **2003** ✓
- Frequency: **2.4 GHZ, SAME AS 11B** ✓
- Speed: **54 MBPS, LIKE 11A** ✓
- Backward compatible: **WITH 11B** ✓
- Issue: Can't mix 11b/11g speeds (slow to 11Mbps)

**802.11n** (WiFi 4):
- Year: **2009** ✓
- Frequency: **2.4 GHZ AND 5 GHZ DUAL-BAND** ✓
- Speed: **600 MBPS MAXIMUM** ✓
- Technology: MIMO (multiple antennas)
- Channels: **MORE CHANNEL OPTIONS** ✓

### WiFi Generations

**WiFi 1** = **802.11B, 11 MBPS, 1999** ✓
**WiFi 2** = **802.11A, 54 MBPS, 1999** ✓
**WiFi 3** = **802.11G, 54 MBPS, 2003** ✓
**WiFi 4** = **802.11N, 600 MBPS, 2009** ✓
**WiFi 5** = **802.11AC, 1.3 GBPS, 2013** ✓
**WiFi 6** = **802.11AX, 9.6 GBPS, 2019** ✓

### Frequency Bands

**2.4 GHz band**:
- Channels: **1-14, DEPENDS ON REGION** ✓
- Non-overlapping: **1, 6, 11 IN USA** ✓
- Bandwidth per channel: **20 MHZ, 40 MHZ WIDE** ✓
- Benefit: **BETTER RANGE, WALL PENETRATION** ✓
- Issue: Congested (WiFi, Bluetooth, microwaves)

**5 GHz band**:
- Channels: **36-165 AVAILABLE** ✓
- Non-overlapping: **MANY MORE THAN 2.4 GHZ** ✓
- Bandwidth: **20, 40, 80 MHZ WIDE** ✓
- Benefit: **LESS CROWDED, HIGHER SPEED** ✓
- Issue: Shorter range, weaker wall penetration

### Channel Assignment

**Problem**: Overlapping channels cause interference

**2.4 GHz channels**:
- Channel 1: 2.412 GHz (covers 2.392-2.432 GHz)
- Channel 6: 2.437 GHz (covers 2.417-2.457 GHz)
- Channel 11: 2.462 GHz (covers 2.442-2.482 GHz)

**Non-overlapping design**:
- Access Point 1: **CHANNEL 1** ✓
- Access Point 2: **CHANNEL 6** ✓
- Access Point 3: **CHANNEL 11** ✓
- Benefit: **MINIMIZE INTERFERENCE** ✓

### SSID (Service Set Identifier)

**Definition**: **NETWORK NAME, BROADCAST TO CLIENTS** ✓
**Example**: "TechCorp-Guest" or "Building-A-WiFi"
**Hidden SSID**:
- Broadcast: **DISABLED, NOT VISIBLE** ✓
- Security: **SECURITY BY OBSCURITY, WEAK** ⚠️
- Visible SSID: **RECOMMENDED, NOT HIDDEN** ✓

### BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier)

**Definition**: **MAC ADDRESS OF ACCESS POINT** ✓
**Purpose**: **UNIQUELY IDENTIFY AP** ✓
**Example**: 00:1A:2B:3C:4D:5E
**ESSID**: Multiple BSSIDs with same SSID (roaming) ✓

## PART 2: WIRELESS DEPLOYMENT

### Site Survey for Wireless Deployment

**Goals**:
- Find: **OPTIMAL AP PLACEMENT** ✓
- Measure: **SIGNAL STRENGTH, DEAD ZONES** ✓
- Identify: **INTERFERENCE SOURCES** ✓

**Tools**:
- WiFi analyzer app: **VISUALIZE SIGNAL, CHANNELS** ✓
- Heat map: **IDENTIFY COVERAGE AREAS** ✓
- Spectrum analyzer: **DETECT INTERFERENCE** ✓

### AP Placement

**Location principles**:
- Centralize: **ROUGHLY CENTER OF AREA** ✓
- Elevate: **HIGHER THAN DEVICES** ✓
- Avoid obstacles: **WALLS, METAL, WATER** ✓
- Spacing: **TYPICALLY 30-50 FEET APART** ✓

**Bad locations**:
- Basement (distance from users)
- Metal closets (shields signal)
- Corners (poor coverage)
- Near microwaves (interference)

### Coverage Planning

**Building**: 40,000 sq ft office (200 ft × 200 ft)

**802.11n coverage**:
- One AP: **COVERS ~4,000-5,000 SQ FT** ✓
- Distance: ~100-150 feet reliable
- Needed APs: 40,000 / 4,500 = **9 APS MINIMUM** ✓

**Overlap**:
- Coverage: **20-30% OVERLAP FOR ROAMING** ✓
- Smooth handoff: **NO DEAD ZONES** ✓

### Wireless Roaming

**Scenario**: Employee moves office → WiFi changes APs

**Roaming types**:
- Same SSID, same subnet: **FAST ROAMING** ✓
- Same SSID, different subnets: **FULL REAUTHENTICATION** ✓
- Different SSID: **RECONNECTION REQUIRED** ✓

## PART 3: WIRELESS PERFORMANCE

### Data Rates and Speeds

**802.11n maximum**:
- Theoretical: 600 Mbps
- Real-world: **150-300 MBPS, 50% OVERHEAD** ✓
- Reason: MAC overhead, collision, retransmission

**WiFi 6 maximum**:
- Theoretical: 9.6 Gbps
- Real-world: **2-3 GBPS, OVERHEAD** ✓

### Signal Strength (RSSI)

**RSSI** = Received Signal Strength Indicator

**Typical values**:
- Excellent: **> -50 DBM, VERY STRONG** ✓
- Good: **-50 TO -60 DBM, STRONG** ✓
- Fair: **-60 TO -70 DBM, ACCEPTABLE** ✓
- Weak: **-70 TO -80 DBM, POOR** ✓
- No signal: **< -80 DBM, DISCONNECTED** ✓

### Channel Bonding (Wider Channels)

**Concept**: **COMBINE ADJACENT CHANNELS FOR SPEED** ✓

**802.11n channels**:
- 20 MHz: Standard, 3 non-overlapping
- 40 MHz: **TWO 20 MHZ CHANNELS COMBINED** ✓
- Benefit: **DOUBLED THROUGHPUT** ✓
- Issue: **ONLY 1 NON-OVERLAPPING COMBO IN 2.4 GHZ** ✓

### Throughput vs Bandwidth

**Bandwidth**:
- Definition: **FREQUENCY RANGE USED** ✓
- Example: 20 MHz channel
- Measurement: Frequency (Hz)

**Throughput**:
- Definition: **ACTUAL DATA RATE ACHIEVED** ✓
- Example: 150 Mbps on 802.11n
- Measurement: bits/second (Mbps)

## PART 4: WIRELESS TECHNOLOGIES

### MIMO (Multiple-Input, Multiple-Output)

**Technology**: **MULTIPLE ANTENNAS FOR BETTER SIGNAL** ✓

**Single antenna** (11a/11g):
- APs: **1 ANTENNA** ✓
- Speed: 54 Mbps

**MIMO** (11n/11ac/11ax):
- APs: **2-8+ ANTENNAS** ✓
- Speed: **HIGHER THROUGHPUT, RELIABILITY** ✓

### Beamforming

**Purpose**: **FOCUS SIGNAL TOWARD CLIENT** ✓
**Benefit**: **IMPROVED SIGNAL, RANGE, THROUGHPUT** ✓
**Support**: **11AC AND LATER** ✓

### MU-MIMO (Multi-User MIMO)

**Traditional MIMO**:
- Service: **ONE CLIENT AT A TIME** ✓
- Issue: **OTHERS WAIT THEIR TURN** ✓

**MU-MIMO** (11ac/11ax):
- Service: **MULTIPLE CLIENTS SIMULTANEOUSLY** ✓
- Benefit: **HIGHER TOTAL THROUGHPUT** ✓

### OFDM (Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing)

**Purpose**: **DIVIDE CHANNEL INTO SUBCARRIERS** ✓
**Benefit**: **ROBUST TO INTERFERENCE, REFLECTION** ✓
**Implementation**: **802.11A AND LATER USE OFDM** ✓

## PART 5: WIRELESS CHALLENGES

### Interference Sources

**2.4 GHz interference**:
- Microwave ovens: **STRONG INTERFERENCE** ⚠️
- Cordless phones: **OVERLAPPING FREQUENCY** ⚠️
- Bluetooth: **SAME 2.4 GHZ BAND** ⚠️
- Other WiFi: **ADJACENT CHANNELS** ⚠️

**Solutions**:
- Use 5 GHz: **LESS CONGESTED** ✓
- Channel selection: **CHANNELS 1, 6, 11** ✓

### Obstacles and Signal Attenuation

**Free space**:
- Path loss: **MINIMAL, CLEAR LINE-OF-SIGHT** ✓
- Signal: Strong

**Obstacles reduce signal**:
- Drywall: **-3 DB, SOME ATTENUATION** ✓
- Wood/glass: **-5 DB** ✓
- Metal doors: **-15 DB, MAJOR** ⚠️
- Concrete: **-10 DB, SIGNIFICANT** ⚠️

### Power Management

**AP transmit power**:
- Range: **1-30 DBM DEPENDING REGION** ✓
- Higher: **MORE RANGE, BUT HIGHER COST** ✓
- Regulation: **FCC LIMITS USA** ✓

**Client power saving**:
- Sleep mode: **REDUCES BATTERY USAGE** ✓
- Wake on wireless: **QUICK RECONNECT** ✓

### Multipath and Fading

**Multipath**:
- Cause: **SIGNAL BOUNCES OFF OBSTACLES** ✓
- Effect: **CONSTRUCTIVE/DESTRUCTIVE INTERFERENCE** ✓
- Result: **VARYING SIGNAL STRENGTH** ✓

**Fading types**:
- Small-scale: **RAPID CHANGES** ✓
- Large-scale: **DISTANCE-BASED ATTENUATION** ✓

## PART 6: WIRELESS STANDARDS EVOLUTION

### 802.11 Improvements Over Time

**Data rate progression**:
- 1997: **1-2 MBPS** ✓
- 1999: **54 MBPS** ✓
- 2009: **600 MBPS** ✓
- 2013: **1.3 GBPS** ✓
- 2019: **9.6 GBPS** ✓

**Drivers**: More antennas, wider channels, better coding ✓

### 6 GHz Spectrum (802.11ax+)

**New band**: **6 GHZ FREQUENCY RANGE** ✓
**Availability**: **NEWER WIFI 6E DEVICES** ✓
**Channels**: **MANY MORE CHANNELS AVAILABLE** ✓
**Benefit**: **LESS CONGESTION, IMPROVED PERFORMANCE** ✓

### Backward Compatibility

**Example**: New 802.11ac AP with old 802.11g client

**What happens**:
- AP detects: **OLD CLIENT PRESENT** ✓
- Operation: **SLOWS TO SUPPORT OLD DEVICE** ✓
- Speed: **LIMITED TO LOWEST CLIENT SPEED** ✓

### Planning for Future

**Deployment checklist**:
- Current needs: **ASSESS BANDWIDTH** ✓
- Growth: **PLAN 3-5 YEAR EXPANSION** ✓
- Standard: **USE LATEST STABLE STANDARD** ✓
- Vendor support: **LONG-TERM UPDATES** ✓
- Budget: **INITIAL + REFRESH COSTS** ✓
hints: 802.11 standards: b/g (2.4 GHz), a/ac (5 GHz), n/ax (both bands); higher generation = faster speed
Frequency bands: 2.4 GHz (better range, congested); 5 GHz (less congested, shorter range)
Non-overlapping channels in 2.4 GHz: Channels 1, 6, 11 (minimize interference)
SSID = network name visible to clients; BSSID = MAC address of AP; ESSID = multiple APs with same SSID
Site survey: Find AP placement, measure signal strength, identify interference before deployment
Coverage: ~4,000-5,000 sq ft per 802.11n AP; plan 20-30% overlap for smooth roaming
Signal strength (RSSI): > -50 dBm (excellent), -60 to -70 dBm (fair), < -80 dBm (no signal)
MIMO = multiple antennas; MU-MIMO = multiple clients simultaneously; Beamforming = focus signal
Interference at 2.4 GHz: Microwaves, Bluetooth, cordless phones; use 5 GHz or channels 1/6/11
Backward compatibility: Old devices slow AP to lowest speed; plan standard carefully
